Date: Wed, 13 Jun 2001 11:30:31 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: Gladiator specs, Part 1
To: gladiator@...
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
From: dph of rules <dph_of_rules@...>

Obviously, I am going to have to send another email to
get the specs for grid files, if no person has cracked
that code.

--- Tom Ricket <tricket@...> wrote:
> Date: Tue, 12 Jun 2001 15:41:19 -0400
> To: dph of rules <dph_of_rules@...>
> From: Tom Ricket <tricket@...>
> Subject: Re: confidential info
> 
> Hiya, dph,
> 
> Sorry for the long delay responding to you -- I was
> out of town until last 
> night, so my e-mail built up.
> 
> >Would it be possible for you to give us the 411 on
> the
> >way the file is formatted to hold the information
> used
> >to create a scenario so that we, the gladiator
> group,
> >could create a newer (hopefully better) scenario
> >editor?
> >
> >Obviously, the new scenario editor would have to be
> >free and password protected like the original one. 
> If
> >signing legal agreements is required, I am sure
> that
> >those working on a new scenario editor would be
> willing.
> 
> Sure .. we'd be happy to have you (or others) muck
> around with it and 
> create something better.  Let me see if I can find
> that documentation ....
> 
> Okay, the scenario files evolved up through version
> 8 .. I'll get you the 
> code for that, since it's the most recent; if you
> need the earlier versions 
> for any reason (you shouldn't, since you can always
> just load an older 
> version in the editor, and re-save it to update it
> to version 8), let me know.
> 
> Here's the file description information (you might
> want to view/print this 
> in a monospaced font):
> 
>    // Format of a scenario object list file version
> 6/7+ is:
>    // 3-byte header: 'FSS'
>    // 1-byte version #
>    // 8-byte string = grid name to load
>    // 30-byte scenario title (ver 6+)
>    // 1-byte char = scenario type, default is 0
>    // 2-bytes par-value, v.8+
>    // 2-bytes (short) = total objects to follow
>    // List of n objects, each of 7-bytes of form:
>           // 1-byte ORDER
>           // 1-byte FAMILY
>           // 2-byte short xpos
>           // 2-byte short ypos
>           // 1-byte TEAM
>           // 1-byte facing
>           // 1-byte command
>           // 1-byte level // 2 bytes in version 7+
>           // 12-bytes name
>           // ---
>           // 10 bytes reserved
>    // 1-byte # of lines of text to load
>    // List of n lines of text, each of form:
>           // 1-byte character width of line
>           // m bytes == characters on this line
> 
> 
> Let me know if you need more information!
> 
> --Tom
>
